description: From Middle English stoupen, from Old English stūpian (“to bow, bend”), from Proto-West Germanic *stūpōn, from Proto-Germanic *stūpōną, *stūpijaną (“to stand out”), from Proto-Indo-European *(s)tewb- (“to push, butt, knock”). Compare steep. Cognate with Dutch stuipen (“to bend the upper part of the body forward and downward”), Old Norse stúpa (“to stoop”). Related also to Old Frisian stēpa (“to help”), Old Norse steypa (“to cause to stoop, cast down, overthrow”).

entries.meaning: A stooping, bent position of the body.
examples: The old man walked with a stoop.

entries.meaning: An accelerated descent in flight, as that for an attack.
examples: At length the hawk got the upper hand, and made a rushing stoop at her quarry

verbs.description: stoop (third-person singular simple present stoops, present participle stooping, simple past and past participle stooped)

entries.meaning: To bend the upper part of the body forward and downward to a half-squatting position; crouch.
examples: He stooped to tie his shoe-laces.

entries.meaning: To lower oneself; to demean or do something below one's status, standards, or morals.
examples: Can you believe that a salesman would stoop so low as to hide his customers' car keys until they agreed to the purchase?

entries.meaning: (intransitive) Of a bird of prey: to swoop down on its prey.
examples: Presently the bird stooped and seized a salmon, and a violent struggle ensued.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause to incline downward; to slant.
examples: to stoop a cask of liquor

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause to submit; to prostrate.
To yield; to submit; to bend, as by compulsion; to assume a position of humility or subjection.
examples: Mighty in her ships stood Carthage long,  […]  / Yet stooped to Rome, less wealthy, but more strong.

entries.meaning: To descend from rank or dignity; to condescend.

description: From Middle English stope, stoupe, from Old Norse staup (“dip, well, cup”), from Proto-Germanic *staupą, related to the verb *staupijaną (“to steep”). Related to Old English stēap (“drinking vessel, cup, flagon, stoop”).

entries.meaning: A vessel for holding liquids; like a flagon but without the spout.

description: Borrowed from Dutch stoep (“platform", "pavement”). Doublet of stoep. Cognate with step.

entries.meaning: (chiefly Northeastern US, chiefly New York, also Canada) The staircase and landing or porch leading to the entrance of a residence.
(US) The threshold of a doorway, a doorstep.

description: From Middle English stoupe, stulpe, from Old Norse stólpi (“post, pillar”), from Proto-Germanic *stulpô.

entries.meaning: (dialect) A post or pillar, especially a gatepost or a support in a mine.
